verses.text: After Jesus had spoken these words, he went out with his disciples across the Kidron Valley, where there was a garden, which he and his disciples entered.
verses.comment: The 'garden' refers to Gethsemane, also mentioned in the Synoptics. This setting points to Jesus as the New Adam, entering a garden to accomplish the redemption of mankind (cf. Gen. 2–3).

verses.text: Now Judas, who was betraying him, also knew the place, because Jesus often met there with his disciples.
verses.comment: Judas's knowledge of this location emphasizes the closeness he previously shared with Jesus, making the betrayal more tragic.

verses.text: So Judas, having received a detachment of soldiers and some officers from the chief priests and the Pharisees, came there with lanterns and torches and weapons.
verses.comment: The presence of both Roman soldiers and Jewish officers shows joint action against Jesus. The use of force highlights the perceived threat and the fulfillment of prophecy regarding the suffering of the Messiah.

verses.text: Then Jesus, knowing everything that would happen to him, went forward and said to them, "Whom do you seek?"
verses.comment: Jesus initiates; his foreknowledge points to his divinity (cf. John 13:1), showing he freely offers himself.

verses.text: They answered him, "Jesus of Nazareth." Jesus said to them, "I am he." Judas, who betrayed him, was standing with them.
verses.comment: Jesus says 'I am he' (Greek: egō eimi), echoing the divine name revealed in Exodus 3:14. This is another example where Jesus indirectly claims divinity.

verses.text: When he said to them, "I am he," they drew back and fell to the ground.
verses.comment: Christ’s divine authority is revealed; at his word, his captors fall. This recalls various theophanies where God's presence causes people to fall (e.g., Ezek. 1:28).

verses.text: Again he asked them, "Whom do you seek?" And they said, "Jesus of Nazareth."
verses.comment: Jesus repeats the question, demonstrating control over the situation and further indicating his willing surrender.

verses.text: Jesus answered, "I told you that I am he. So if you seek me, let these men go."
verses.comment: Jesus's concern for his disciples reflects the Good Shepherd laying down his life for the flock. This anticipates the idea of substitution and self-offering.

verses.text: This was to fulfill the word that he had spoken: "Of those you gave me, I have lost not one."
verses.comment: Jesus' words fulfill his earlier promise, showing the trustworthiness and completeness of his mission and his role as protector.

verses.text: Then Simon Peter, having a sword, drew it and struck the high priest’s servant and cut off his right ear. The servant’s name was Malchus.
verses.comment: Peter’s impulsiveness is shown. Only John provides the names of Peter and Malchus; this detail adds historical credibility.

verses.text: So Jesus said to Peter, "Put your sword into its sheath; shall I not drink the cup the Father has given me?"
verses.comment: The 'cup' refers to his suffering, echoing Old Testament symbolism (see Isa. 51:17). Jesus willingly accepts the Father’s will, modeling obedience.

verses.text: Then the detachment of soldiers, their captain, and the officers of the Jews arrested Jesus and bound him.
verses.comment: Jesus, though divine, submits himself to his captors, prefiguring his offering as the true Paschal Lamb.

verses.text: First they led him to Annas, who was the father-in-law of Caiaphas, the high priest that year.
verses.comment: Annas was a former high priest and influential figure. Jesus faces several quasi-legal hearings, underlining the irregularity of his trial.

verses.text: Caiaphas was the one who had advised the Jews that it would be better for one man to die for the people.
verses.comment: Caiaphas’s prophecy, though meant politically, is fulfilled theologically as Jesus dies to save many (cf. Isa. 53:11-12).

verses.text: Simon Peter followed Jesus, along with another disciple. Since that disciple was known to the high priest, he entered with Jesus into the courtyard of the high priest.
verses.comment: Tradition often identifies the 'other disciple' as John. His access to the courtyard gives an eyewitness testimony.

verses.text: But Peter stood outside at the door. So the other disciple, who was known to the high priest, went out and spoke to the girl who kept watch at the door and brought Peter in.
verses.comment: The narrative detail emphasizes historical accuracy. Peter's entry sets up his impending denial.

verses.text: Then the servant girl who kept watch at the door said to Peter, "You are not also one of this man’s disciples, are you?" He said, "I am not."
verses.comment: Peter’s fear leads to denial, fulfilling Jesus’ prophecy (John 13:38). Even leaders can falter, but later be restored.

verses.text: Now the servants and the officers were standing there, having made a charcoal fire because it was cold. They were warming themselves, and Peter was also with them, standing and warming himself.
verses.comment: The detail of the charcoal fire creates a literary connection to Peter’s later restoration (John 21:9).

verses.text: The high priest then questioned Jesus about his disciples and his teaching.
verses.comment: This is an informal interrogation. The authorities are concerned about Jesus’ influence.

verses.text: Jesus answered him, "I have spoken openly to the world. I always taught in synagogues and in the temple, where all Jews come together. I have said nothing in secret.
verses.comment: Jesus emphasizes the public nature of his ministry, contrasting with the clandestine nature of his arrest and trial.

verses.text: Why do you ask me? Ask those who have heard what I said to them. They know what I said."
verses.comment: Proper legal procedure would have called for witnesses; Jesus exposes their injustice.

verses.text: When he said this, one of the officers standing by struck Jesus with his hand, saying, "Is that how you answer the high priest?"
verses.comment: Jesus' suffering fulfills prophecy (Isa. 50:6) of the righteous servant being struck and humiliated.

verses.text: Jesus answered him, "If I spoke wrongly, testify to the wrong; but if I spoke rightly, why do you strike me?"
verses.comment: Jesus upholds justice and fairness even in the face of violence. He models non-retaliation.

verses.text: Then Annas sent him, still bound, to Caiaphas the high priest.
verses.comment: This brief mention bridges Jesus from initial questioning to the more formal trial, highlighting the chain of authority.

verses.text: Now Simon Peter was standing and warming himself. So they said to him, "You are not also one of his disciples, are you?" He denied it and said, "I am not."
verses.comment: Peter's second denial illustrates human weakness, but also prepares for his later restoration as a leader whose authority endures by the grace of Christ.

verses.text: One of the servants of the high priest, a relative of the man whose ear Peter had cut off, said, "Did I not see you in the garden with him?"
verses.comment: The question comes from direct observation, highlighting the risk Peter faces and increasing the tension.

verses.text: Peter then denied it again, and at once a rooster crowed.
verses.comment: This immediate fulfillment of Jesus' prophecy about Peter’s denial highlights Christ’s foreknowledge and Peter’s remorse, encouraging mercy and restoration.

verses.text: Then they led Jesus from the house of Caiaphas to the governor's headquarters. It was early morning. They themselves did not enter the headquarters, so that they would not be defiled and could eat the Passover.
verses.comment: The religious leaders seek ritual purity while condemning the innocent—an irony. The mention of Passover shows Jesus as the true Lamb.

verses.text: So Pilate went outside to them and said, "What accusation do you bring against this man?"
verses.comment: Roman involvement fulfills the prophecy of the Messiah's suffering at the hands of the nations (see Ps. 2:1-2).

verses.text: They answered him, "If this man were not doing evil, we would not have handed him over to you."
verses.comment: The vague accusation illustrates the weakness of their case but also the fulfillment of the suffering servant motif.

verses.text: Pilate said to them, "Take him yourselves and judge him by your own law." The Jews said to him, "It is not lawful for us to put anyone to death."
verses.comment: Capital punishment required Roman consent, fulfilling the prophecy that the Messiah would be lifted up (John 12:32-33).

verses.text: This was to fulfill what Jesus had spoken to show by what kind of death he was going to die.
verses.comment: Crucifixion (being 'lifted up') fulfills Jesus’ prophecy and Old Testament types such as the bronze serpent (Num. 21:9).

verses.text: So Pilate entered his headquarters again and called Jesus and said to him, "Are you the King of the Jews?"
verses.comment: The messianic kingship is questioned; echoes Old Testament prophecies of a coming King from David’s line.

verses.text: Jesus answered, "Do you say this on your own, or did others tell you about me?"
verses.comment: Jesus’ question implies Pilate should personally engage with who Jesus is—a recurring theme for all listeners of the Gospel.

verses.text: Pilate answered, "Am I a Jew? Your own nation and the chief priests have delivered you over to me. What have you done?"
verses.comment: Pilate distances himself from the issue, showing the injustice and abandonment Jesus suffered even from his own people.

verses.text: Jesus answered, "My kingdom is not of this world. If my kingdom were of this world, my servants would have been fighting, that I might not be delivered over to the Jews. But my kingdom is not from here."
verses.comment: Jesus claims a spiritual kingdom, fulfilling messianic prophecy but redefining expectations. The reference to his 'servants' not fighting aligns with Christ's peace and the spiritual nature of the Church as his kingdom on earth and in heaven.

verses.text: Then Pilate said to him, "So you are a king?" Jesus answered, "You say that I am a king. For this purpose I was born and for this purpose I have come into the world—to bear witness to the truth. Everyone who is of the truth listens to my voice."
verses.comment: Jesus’ kingship is grounded in truth and bears on all who listen to his voice, referencing the Shepherd motif. This authority is ultimately spiritual and universal.

verses.text: Pilate said to him, "What is truth?" After he had said this, he went out to the Jews again and told them, "I find no guilt in him."
verses.comment: The question, 'What is truth?', reveals Pilate’s skepticism. Pilate’s declaration of innocence fulfills prophecy (Isa. 53:9, 'he had done no violence').

verses.text: But you have a custom that I should release one man for you at the Passover. So do you want me to release to you the King of the Jews?"
verses.comment: The Passover custom, unique to the period, sets the stage for the crowd's rejection of Jesus, the true Paschal Lamb.

verses.text: They cried out again, "Not this man, but Barabbas!" Now Barabbas was a robber.
verses.comment: The choice of Barabbas (a violent criminal) over Jesus fulfills the prophecy that the servant would be 'despised and rejected by men' (Isa. 53:3) and reveals the tragic irony of the crowd’s decision. The acceptance of a false liberator over the True King points to the ongoing need for the Church, as the true community of Christ’s followers, to faithfully discern and receive the authentic Messiah.
